article:
A 'four-quadrant gate' is a type of boom barrier gate protecting a grade
crossing. It has a gate mechanism on both sides of the tracks for both
directions of automotive traffic. The exit gates blocking the road leading away
from the tracks in this application are equipped with a delay, and begin their
descent to their horizontal position several seconds after the entrance gates
do, so as to avoid trapping highway vehicles on the crossing. Four-quadrant
gates are safer than two-quadrant gates because they prevent drivers from
illegally driving their vehicles around lowered gates to try to beat a train.

In the UK, such crossings are categorised as 'Manually Controlled Barriers'
(MCB) because they are always manually controlled, usually from a signal box.
Some are known as MCB-CCTV level crossings, because they are supervised by video
link to the signal box from which they are remotely controlled.
